title: Government warns school lunch boxes breed bacteria and could be making your kids SICK
text:
Parents are being warned about the risks of incorrectly packing their children's lunch boxes and inadvertently making them sick.

The South Australian Department for Health and Wellbeing has advised parents of the dangers of harmful bacteria forming inside hot lunch boxes at school.

Hot lunch boxes provide a setting for dangerous pathogens to develop, causing food products to go off quickly.

Parents have been warned about the risks of poorly packing their children's lunch boxes and making them sick (stock image)

These pathogens leave children at risk of developing food poisoning and other stomach ailments.

Parents have been urged to take care when packing lunches and to make sure that food is being stored correctly to avoid any risk.

Manager of Food Standards Surveillance Alessia Centofanti told 7News parents should pack an ice brick in lunch boxes to minimise the risk of bacteria.

'A lunchbox with a frozen drink or ice brick will keep food at a safe temperature until lunchtime at school, however, some foods are more sensitive to heat and will grow dangerous bacteria quicker,' she said.

Foods to avoid include dairy products, meats and rice.

Putting foods into separate containers can also help to stop bacteria developing.
description: The South Australian Department for Health and Wellbeing has advised parents of the dangers of harmful bacteria forming inside hot lunch boxes at school.
authors: Jackson Barron For Daily Mail Australia
